adriaan monshouwer
business stategist & consultant at pictureinside.nl; visual stories editor, curator & connector at onlinephotoeditor.nl; former secretary of the jury of WPPF
Jan 25

Creating a community of visual storytellers

An interview with Giuseppe Oliverio of the Photographic Museum of Humanity

Born in Italy, Giuseppe Oliverio moved to Buenos Aires in 2011 to develop the Photographic Museum of Humanity (PHmuseum), a curated online platform for contemporary photography. The platform was launched in 2012 and today hosts a community of 5,000 photographers and welcomes 300,000 visitors a year. I interviewed Giuseppe to find out what motivated him to create PHMuseum and what he wants to achieve for visual storytellers.

What is your personal relationship with photography?

I consider photography as a great source of inspiration, a way to discover and investigate more about the world where we live; its issues, its beauty. I see it as a way to understand and enrich my personal background, a starting point to many personal and universal journeys.

What do you see as the biggest challenges for photographers today — and tomorrow?

A big challenge photographers are facing is certainly to find a way to keep dedicating the proper time to their personal long-term projects. With lower average incomes across countries, the risk is to see more and more superficial works.

I believe there is no simple solution to this issue, but in my opinion, a photographer should start by being very well organized and understanding quickly which could be his/her steady sources of income, such as advertising and/or editorial assignments, Instagram-related opportunities, working with NGOs, selling prints and books, etcetera. A certain stability generally makes things easier.

I know it requires a lot of work and passion, but as a Brazilian curator once told me in an interview, photographers nowadays should strive to be 50 percent Excel and 50 percent PowerPoint. Organizational skills are as important as creativity.

You give workshops and talks on photography 2.0. What do you tell your audience?

I introduce them to photography in the Internet era and provide practical leads to take advantage of the opportunities it offers. Platforms like Facebook and Instagram have changed the way photography circulates and is consumed.

Nowadays, there is a continuous live interaction between photographers (and their photographs) and viewers, something that was not possible in the paper magazine era before the advent of social media. There has been a change from 2004 onwards and the visual language is quickly adapting to it.

It is important to understand these evolving dynamics. As a photographer, for example, you can take advantage of them by developing and engaging an audience towards your work on social media. You can crowdfund and publish your own book. You can get in touch with photo editors with platforms like PHmuseum and sell your work to magazines in countries or even continents that would have been out of your reach. You can apply to many grants and awards to finance your projects and get your work known within and outside the industry.

The competition is obviously higher and sometimes we take these opportunities for granted, but if we think about it in perspective it is a great revolution. Our industry is already reaching a broader audience than it used to 15–20 years ago when magazines and galleries represented almost the only way to make works circulating. We all need to adapt to this change in the paradigm and become more enterprising.

What was your motivation to start the PHmuseum project?

I wanted to create a space where people from all over the world could access curated visual contents and learn about photography and its language. In many regions its still very difficult, if not impossible, to have access to museums, galleries, photography schools and photo books. At the same time around 40 percent of the world’s population has access to the internet. For this reason I was — and still am—really enthusiastic and fascinated by the idea of developing an online platform like PHmuseum.

As we speak, young folks from Bolivia, Germany or Indonesia can access the work of 5,000 selected photographers, navigate our curated exhibitions, read our articles, write to photographers and get closer to contemporary photography. Clearly, we still have a lot of work to do in order to improve our services and reach our main goal, but I think our current platform represents a solid base.

Who do you want to connect and why is that important?

We are using today’s technological opportunities to connect people within the visual industry among themselves and with a wider audience. We started five years ago by connecting photographers with the general public and in the last couple of years we have worked to facilitate photographers’ interactions with photo editors and curators.

Simplifying the way professionals connect with each other and the general public is something very important for many reasons. Ideas circulate faster and generate new ones. We can exchange opinions and learn from each other. Visual stories can reach a broader and more proper audience.

When will the exhibition section of the website go live?

We launched a significantly renewed version of our platform around a year ago and opted to dedicate the proper time to re-conceive the exhibition section. It went live last week and you can currently visit our first show on migrations.

What are the criteria to accept photographers?

Almost all kinds of photography are welcome, from classic photojournalism to innovative and experimental projects. What’s important for us at the moment of reviewing a photographer’s portfolio is to see a fluent narrative across works, clear concepts and ideas, a solid technical level and possibly innovative approaches to visual language.

Do you curate or edit the stories that photographers upload?

Photographers are free to decide which stories they prefer to upload and we do not interfere in the editing process. What we do is constantly review them and highlight the most interesting in our curated sections, like Story of the Week. The same goes for our News contributors, who write about projects from our community that they consider relevant.

How do you facilitate the interaction with photo editors and media companies?

Our platform offers two main services in this sense. The first one is the Advanced Search. It allows photo editors, curators and all those people with an interest in the image to browse our curated archive of visual stories. You can search, for example, for all the stories on climate change shot in United States. Or you can search for all the stories shot by Argentinian photographers, and so on. The Advanced Search also enables you to search for photographers according to several parameters, like where they’re based, their nationality and age, the languages they speak, and so on. The Advanced Search is currently a free service available to all the registered users of our platform.

The second service is called Make An Offer and enables the approved photo editors of our network to make monetary offers to purchase the rights to publish the visual stories featured on PHmuseum. This service enables photo editors to make offers in a single step, facilitates the file transfers, simplifies the invoicing system and grants quicker transactions. If the transaction is successful (i.e. if the photographer accepts the offer) we take a 15 percent commission.

How would you describe and label the platform?

The platform has two souls: the Community, where we facilitate the interactions among professionals of the photography industry, and the Museum that represents our editorial voice. I do not like labels, but if I had to choose two words I would say Professional and Editorial Platform (dedicated to contemporary photography).

Is there any interaction and contact between the photographers?

There is, but it is mostly behind the scenes. Photographers often discover new colleagues and their works thanks to our platform, but do not tend to comment or follow each other as you see on other social networks. We are currently working to incentivize those kinds of interactions, though.

What is the business model? What are your revenue streams?

We generate revenue by taking a commission on successful transactions between photographers and photo editors. We also collaborate directly with media companies on specific projects. Another source of revenue comes from curating exhibitions or offering consultancy. The costs we are bearing to develop the platform are pretty high, but we should reach break-even in 2017.

And the grant?

This is our first grant with an application fee, so we don’t have numbers yet. Our first goal is to offer a significant monetary prize and concrete opportunities to further photographers’ careers and contribute in the circulation of new, meaningful works. If the response from photographers is very positive and we receive many applications, we’ll reinvest potential revenues to improve the platform and create new opportunities.

What makes PHmuseum special?

PHmuseum welcomes photographers from the 5 continents, covering areas like South America or Africa, where it’s more difficult to find photographers and works. It offers more than 8,000 selected visual stories and modern tools to search and purchase them. Our strength is to be a curated, dynamic and modern platform constantly updated by its users.

What are your ideas for the near future?

Our archive of projects is constantly evolving and depends on photographers, who own the rights to their work. We do not have a permanent collection at the moment, but it might be an option for the future, together with creating our own archive of photographs. Regarding education, we have a couple of very interesting ideas for 2018 that we are currently discussing.

Do you see differences between photojournalism, documentary photography and visual storytelling?

Yes, I see differences. I consider photojournalism as the equivalent of documentary filmmaking. It tries to portray an event or tell a story sticking to facts. While I see visual storytelling closer to fiction movies, a way to tell original stories and explore new territories. Documentary photography instead is something that floats in between, trying to get the best of both worlds. It is clearly an oversimplification; there are blurred boundaries among them and we could spend a week trying to define them, probably without succeeding.

I think it is more important to focus on the thing they have in common and that is that none of them is objective and unbiased, since all of them incorporate the point of view of the photographer, who is a human being, not a machine. I think it is important for viewers to understand that, discriminate between reliable and unreliable sources, and draw their own conclusions. This is hardly possible if people do not have a visual education. For this reason, I think it is the responsibility of all the players in our industry to work together and get the general public closer and more familiar with the visual language.
